title: Stuart Evans
text:
Stuart Evans (born 14 June 1963) is a Welsh former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> and <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1980s and 1990s. Born in <a href="Neath">Neath</a> in 1963, Evans played for several rugby union clubs, including <a href="Corus%20%28Port%20Talbot%29%20RFC">British Steel</a>, for whom he once worked, <a href="Resolven%20RFC">Resolven</a>, <a href="Swansea%20RFC">Swansea</a>, <a href="Western%20Suburbs%20Rugby%20Football%20Club">Western Suburbs</a>, <a href="Neath%20RFC">Neath</a> and <a href="Barbarian%20F.C.">Barbarian F.C.</a>. Between 1985 and 1987, Evans played for the <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales national rugby union team</a> on nine occasions, and played in the <a href="1987%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">1987 Rugby World Cup</a>. In September 1987 he switched codes to rugby league, joining <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a>
John Player Special Trophy Final appearances.
Stuart Evans played as an <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Interchange">interchange</a>/<a href="Substitution%20%28sport%29">substitute</a>, i.e. number 15, (replacing <a href="Peter%20Souto">Peter Souto</a>) in <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a>' 15–14 victory over <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> in the <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1987–88</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">John Player Special Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1987–88 season</a> at <a href="Central%20Park%20%28Wigan%29">Central Park</a>, <a href="Wigan">Wigan</a> on Saturday 9 January 1988.
A French championship Title private following a refereeing error with Grenoble 1993.
He has played for the <a href="FC%20Grenoble">FC Grenoble</a> and despite overpowering pack called the Mammoths of Grenoble his club tilts on the score of 14–11.
A try on his part is also refused in Grenoble and the decisive try by <a href="Gary%20Whetton">Gary Whetton</a> was awarded by the referee, <a href="Daniel%20Salles">Daniel Salles</a>, when in fact the defender <a href="Franck%20Hueber">Franck Hueber</a> from Grenoble touched down the ball first in his try zone.
This error gave the title to <a href="Castres%20Olympique">Castres Olympique</a>. Salles admitted the error 13 years later.
<a href="Jacques%20Fouroux">Jacques Fouroux</a> the coach of FC Grenoble in conflict with the Federation and who was already suspicious before the match of the referee cry out conspiracy.
